Articles.Content:
Wasnt sure weather to mark as a suggestion or a discussion so went for the latter.

I may well be the only one but it seems like my kerbals and a few of my lighter vehicles seem to slide areound a bit too much. I've been doing a lot of MUN stuff recently and have noticed that my kerbals slide an awfully long way when they fall down a hill...just sliding and sliding.

I know that in reality you would probably do alot of rolling around as if you slipped down a hill on the moon but it just seems so unnatural in ksp.

Am i the only one who sees this? I am pretty stupid
so far the only things that have friction are the wheels and landing gear, but other than that, yes stuff does slide around quite a bit...
Sliding is a great way to cover big distances fast and without wasting all of your EVA fuel, but yes a little more friction wouldn't hurt.
A lot more friction on Minmus...

Actually the problem with most rovers is too much friction. The wheels have no slip if they go sideways so the entire craft flips.

On the other hand I too have had a kerbal face-slide a good half a kilometer after hitting the ground too hard on his way to the rescue vehicle.

I usually have less problems with friction and more problems with gravity. Minmus seems to be the biggest culprit, I had a small rover there that I landed and it flipped end over end for, literally, 40 minutes. I went out to dinner and came back to it still flipping. I eventually had to redesign it to spread out its mass a bit more so it wouldn't flip as easily.

I also lost a Kerbal on EVA due to the way it came down on an unassisted jump. The Kerbal bounced, then bounced over a ridge which gave it far too much air time so it landed face first at about 20 m/s. Crunch went the Kerbal.

Yeah, I hate Minmus.
